name: Lusaka
fun_fact: Fun fact: Nshima, Zambia's national dish, is eaten by hand using the right hand only. Diners shape the thick maize porridge into a ball, make an indentation with their thumb, and use it as an edible scoop for relish. This communal eating method has been practiced for centuries and enhances the social aspect of meals. Zambia has over 72 tribes across 10 provinces, each with unique cooking techniques but unified by the sacred nshima.

hero_dishes.name: Nshima with Ifisashi
hero_dishes.description: Thick maize porridge (nshima) served with a creamy groundnut and greens stew - the soul of Zambian cuisine
hero_dishes.origin_story: Nshima is the cornerstone of Zambian identity, eaten at lunch and dinner by all 72 tribes. Made from finely milled mealie meal mixed with hot water until thick, it's shaped by hand into portions. Ifisashi combines indigenous leafy greens (kalembula sweet potato leaves, chibwabwa pumpkin leaves, or mpilu blackjack leaves) with groundnut paste, creating a rich, nutty vegetarian stew that locals have eaten for generations.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: New Soweto Market (first restaurant established in the market serves traditional lunch), Matebeto Restaurants throughout Lusaka, local family dining experiences in homes

hero_dishes.name: Chikanda (African Polony)
hero_dishes.description: Unique vegetarian 'meat' made from wild orchid tubers, groundnuts, and chili - can be snack, dessert, side, or main course
hero_dishes.origin_story: Originating from the Bemba tribe in northeastern Zambia, chikanda is made by drying and grinding wild orchid tubers, then mixing with peanuts and chili. Despite being fully vegetarian, it has a distinctive meaty texture, earning it the nickname 'African Polony.' Foraging the orchid tubers requires traditional knowledge passed down through families.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors in Lusaka markets, New Soweto Market, Chisokone Market in Kitwe

hero_dishes.name: Kapenta with Tomato-Onion Relish
hero_dishes.description: Tiny sardine-like fish from Lake Tanganyika, sun-dried and fried with onions and tomatoes
hero_dishes.origin_story: Kapenta are caught at night using nets and lights on Lake Tanganyika and Lake Kariba. The fish are salted and sun-dried on wooden racks, providing crucial protein and income for lakeside communities. This preservation method allows the fish to travel inland to cities like Lusaka, where they're fried crispy and served with nshima.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Local markets (Soweto, Chisokone), Matebeto restaurants, street food stalls

hero_dishes.name: Mopane Worms (Ifinkubala)
hero_dishes.description: Protein-rich caterpillars soaked, then fried with onions and tomatoes - a crunchy delicacy
hero_dishes.origin_story: These emperor moth caterpillars are harvested from mopane trees during specific seasons. Rich in protein, they've been a traditional food source for centuries. The preparation involves squeezing out the insides, drying, then rehydrating and frying. While it sounds exotic to outsiders, locals consider them a cherished seasonal treat.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Soweto Market during harvest season, rural markets, traditional Zambian homes

signature_drinks.name: Munkoyo
signature_drinks.description: Traditional fermented beverage made from munkoyo plant roots and corn flour - slightly sweet and sour
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: This indigenous drink is made by thickening corn flour with boiling water, adding munkoyo roots, and fermenting overnight. The roots give it a unique milky appearance and subtle fermentation. Served cold, it complements meat and fish dishes perfectly. Each family has their own fermentation technique.

signature_drinks.name: Thobwa
signature_drinks.description: Sweet, porridge-like drink made from millet or sorghum flour with high carbohydrate content
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Popular in eastern Zambia, thobwa is both a refreshing beverage and an energy-boosting breakfast. Made from simple ingredients (sugar, water, millet/sorghum flour), it's enjoyed warm or cold. Market vendors sell it in the morning to workers needing quick energy.

signature_drinks.name: Chibuku Shake-Shake
signature_drinks.description: Traditional beer made from maize and sorghum, unfiltered with a sour taste
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Sold in distinctive cardboard cartons, you literally shake it before drinking (hence 'shake-shake'). The cloudy, sour beer is enjoyed at local gatherings and taverns. It's affordable, nutritious, and deeply woven into Zambian social life.

food_culture_notes: New Soweto Market in downtown Lusaka offers guided food tours showing diversity of foods trucked from all corners of Zambia
Communal eating is central to Zambian culture - food is shared among family and friends as a sign of warmth and hospitality
Matebeto Restaurants are casual traditional eateries found in most cities, serving authentic local dishes unavailable in hotels
Over 72 tribes means incredible culinary diversity, but nshima unifies everyone as the national staple
Home dining experiences allow visitors to taste dishes rarely found in restaurants, cooked by families showcasing their tribal heritage
